--- In junit@y..., Andrew Clarke <andrew.clarke@c...> wrote:

> Whereas if you can make an assertion about something e.g. 
> 	assertNotNull(someArgument);
> then you have anticipated it and therefore can handle it within 
your code
> e.g.
> 	if (someArgument == null) {
> 		displayMessage("You must enter a value"); // or 
whatever
> 	}

Good point, I was perhaps being somewhat simplitic saying there was 
assertion OR exception.  You could have code like the above.

a) if( !databaseIsOpen() )  
      openDatabase();
b) if( !databaseIsOpen() ) 
      throw DatabseAccessException( "db not open" );
c) assert( databaseIsOpen() );

The above are three possible ways to handle an error.  I would choose 
one depending on the situation.  

They kind of move from most expected, to least expected and from most 
ability to deal with it, to least.

I'd use (a) when I can fix the problem right there, (b) if I can't, 
but someone higher up can, or (c) if basically, we're screwed.

If we've got a bug that makes us screwed, I'm not going to handle it 
as there's no point, I want to get the hell out of the system as soon 
as possible so I don't mess anything up.

Alan
subject: Re: Programming By Contract
